questions.question: Why did India conduct the first nuclear test at Pokharan?

questions.question: Describe the development of atomic energy in India under Dr. Homi Bhabha.
questions.answer: Dr. Homi Bhabha was the first Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission established in 1948. Under his leadership, the commission aimed to produce electricity, improve agriculture, and develop technology. The first reactor 'Apsara' was set up in 1956. Later, atomic power stations like Tarapur (1969) and research centres at Kalpakkam were established to advance atomic energy capabilities.

questions.question: Explain the significance of the Pokharan-I nuclear test.
questions.answer: Conducted on 18th May 1974, Pokharan-I was India's first nuclear test. It was a strategic move for peace and self-sufficiency in response to the nuclear capabilities of neighbors China and Pakistan. The successful test demonstrated India's technological capability, despite subsequent technology denials by the USA.

questions.question: Discuss the missile development programme of India.
questions.answer: Under the DRDO and leadership of Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam, India initiated the Integrated Guided Missile Development Programme (IGMDP). It successfully developed the Prithvi (surface-to-surface), Agni (long-range), Akash (surface-to-air), and Nag (anti-tank) missiles. This programme made India militarily secure and self-reliant in defence technology.

questions.question: What was the role of the Bhaskar satellites?
questions.answer: Bhaskar-1 (1979) and Bhaskar-2 (1981) were remote sensing satellites launched from Russia. They were used to observe the earth's surface, aiding in the study of water bodies, mineral deposits, forests, and environment. The data was crucial for oceanography and weather forecasting.

questions.question: How has INSAT technology benefited India?
questions.answer: Launched in 1983, INSAT-1B revolutionized telecommunications, TV, radio, and weather forecasting. It connected 207 radio stations. It aids in disaster management (cyclones, crashes), telemedicine by connecting rural centers to super-specialty hospitals, and supports educational broadcasting.

questions.question: Write a note on the progress of Indian Railways technology.
questions.answer: Indian Railways modernized with the setting up of Chittaranjan Locomotive Works for engine manufacturing. The Diesel Locomotive Works at Varanasi produced the first diesel engine. Computerized reservation started in Delhi in 1984. Metro services began in Kolkata (1984) and Delhi. The Konkan Railway (1998) is a technological marvel with its tunnels and bridges.

questions.question: Describe the evolution of telecommunication services in India.
questions.answer: It started with the Telex service in 1963. Satellite communication earth stations were set up in 1967 (Ahmedabad) and 1970 (Pune). The Pincode system began in 1972. ISD started in 1976. VSNL became a major internet provider in the 90s. Mobile services launched in 1994. BSNL was formed in 2000 to provide services like cellular, internet, and broadband.

questions.question: Explain the features of the Konkan Railway.
questions.answer: Started in 1998, the Konkan Railway spans 760 km across Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, and Kerala. It features 92 tunnels (longest being Karbude 6.5 km) and 179 big and 1819 small bridges. It includes sensors on engines to prevent accidents in landslide-prone areas, showcasing advanced engineering.

questions.question: What is the Pincode system and why was it introduced?
questions.answer: Introduced on 15th August 1972, the Postal Index Code (Pincode) is a six-digit system intended to bring efficiency to mail distribution. It divides the country into regions. The digits indicate the region, sub-region, district, and local post office, streamlining the sorting and delivery process.

questions.question: Write about the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC).
questions.answer: Established in 1956 to search for mineral oil and gas deposits, ONGC found deposits in Ankleshwar and the Gulf of Khambhat. In 1974, it started digging in 'Bombay High' using the drillship 'Sagar Samrat'. This area became a major source, contributing significantly to India's oil and gas production.
